articles.headline: Strong Labor Market Steadied Social Security and Medicare Funds
articles.snippet: The social safety net programs continue to face long-term shortfalls as lawmakers wrestle over changes.
articles.abstract: The social safety net programs continue to face long-term shortfalls as lawmakers wrestle over changes.
articles.lead_paragraph: The financial health of Social Security and Medicare, two of the nation’s most crucial safety net programs, improved this year as a stronger-than-expected economy attracted more workers to the labor market. But the overall financial outlook of the popular programs remained grim.
articles.byline: By Alan Rappeport and Margot Sanger-Katz

articles.headline: Israel Orders Partial Evacuation of Rafah, Fueling Fears of New Offensive
articles.snippet: Hamas says it has agreed to a cease-fire plan that Israel said did not meet its demands, the latest in a long series of negotiating stumbles.
articles.abstract: Hamas says it has agreed to a cease-fire plan that Israel said did not meet its demands, the latest in a long series of negotiating stumbles.
articles.lead_paragraph: Israeli warplanes pounded targets in the southern Gaza city of Rafah on Monday as the military told about 110,000 people sheltering there to evacuate. Many people began to leave, fearing that Israel was moving ahead with its long-planned invasion of Rafah, despite stiff international pressure.
articles.byline: By Vivek Shankar, Liam Stack, Adam Rasgon and Michael Levenson

articles.headline: TV News Can’t Sidestep Turbulence as Election Approaches
articles.snippet: ABC, NBC, CBS and CNN all face questions about their future, just as one of the toughest journalistic assignments looms.
articles.abstract: ABC, NBC, CBS and CNN all face questions about their future, just as one of the toughest journalistic assignments looms.
articles.lead_paragraph: Television news may have never been this unsettled six months before a presidential election.

articles.headline: Behind Nigeria’s Arrest of Binance Employee, Claims of a Bribe Request
articles.snippet: A compliance officer for the cryptocurrency exchange told senior executives and Nigerian contacts that the company had been asked to pay $150 million in crypto.
articles.abstract: A compliance officer for the cryptocurrency exchange told senior executives and Nigerian contacts that the company had been asked to pay $150 million in crypto.
articles.lead_paragraph: On a trip to Nigeria in January, Tigran Gambaryan, a compliance officer for the giant cryptocurrency exchange Binance, received an unsettling message: The company had 48 hours to make a payment of roughly $150 million in crypto.
articles.byline: By David Yaffe-Bellany and Emily Flitter

articles.headline: In Berkeley Public Schools, a War Gives Rise to Unusual Tensions
articles.snippet: Accusations of antisemitism in K-12 schools have fractured a city long known for its progressive ideals and inclusiveness.
articles.abstract: Accusations of antisemitism in K-12 schools have fractured a city long known for its progressive ideals and inclusiveness.
articles.lead_paragraph: The controversy began with a walkout.

articles.headline: Biden Condemns a ‘Ferocious Surge’ of Antisemitism in the United States
articles.snippet: President Biden’s speech at a Holocaust remembrance ceremony came during weeks of protests on U.S. college campuses against Israel’s war in Gaza.
articles.abstract: President Biden’s speech at a Holocaust remembrance ceremony came during weeks of protests on U.S. college campuses against Israel’s war in Gaza.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Biden on Tuesday condemned a “ferocious surge of antisemitism” in the United States following the Oct. 7 Hamas attack against Israel and said people were already forgetting the deadliest day for Jews since the Holocaust.
articles.byline: By Erica L. Green and Michael D. Shear

articles.headline: TikTok Sues U.S. Government Over Law Forcing Sale or Ban
articles.snippet: The social media company and its Chinese parent, ByteDance, sued to challenge the new law, saying it violated users’ First Amendment rights.
articles.abstract: The social media company and its Chinese parent, ByteDance, sued to challenge the new law, saying it violated users’ First Amendment rights.
articles.lead_paragraph: TikTok sued the federal government on Tuesday over a new law that would force its Chinese owner, ByteDance, to sell the popular social media app or face a ban in the United States, stoking a battle over national security and free speech that is likely to end up in the Supreme Court.
articles.byline: By Sapna Maheshwari and David McCabe
